# 2020-04-21
```{r}
# notice: use first column as row.names
D=read.delim2("~/R/Rstudio/Projects/RstudioIntro1/luciferase.tsv", row.names=1)

# transformation: 
# 1) base:barplot needs matrix not data frame 
# 2) log is more meaningful --> avoid gaps

M=as.matrix(log(D))
```

```{r plot}
palette(rainbow(4,alpha=0.7)) # set some meaningful palette
 
# Notice that the color assignment assume an implicit understanding of the data
barplot(M, beside = TRUE, col=1:4)
legend("topleft", legend = rownames(M),  fill = 1:4)

# Probably closer
cols=rep(1:4, each=3)
sp=c(0.2, 1)
barplot(t(M), beside = TRUE, col=cols, space = sp)
legend("topleft", legend = colnames(M),  fill = cols)

```
Problems:
- no easy way to plot error bars on barplots (discouraged) --> boxplot
- no easy way to plot gap on axis --> plotrix:gap.barplot --> better: log-transform
- no way for R to know groups: only humans take interpretation of column names


# The ggplot way
powerful, but forces the adoption of some grammar rules
```{r}
D=read.delim2("~/R/Rstudio/Projects/RstudioIntro1/luciferase.tsv") # keep the Treatment as column

# 1. reformat the data
# observation: two categorical variables (Treatment, Condition), 1 measurement (number)
# Gather all columns and 
#   collect them as categorical variable ("Cond"),
#   call the observed value = "number"
#   don't do this for variable "Treatment"
D %>% gather(Cond, number, -Treatment) %>% head

# now deal with Condition variable - thankfully this is easy (just remove suffix .1 and .2)
D = D %>% gather(Cond, number, -Treatment) %>% mutate(Cond=str_remove(Cond,".\\d"))
```

```{r barplot}
Db = D %>% group_by(Treatment, Cond) %>% summarize(mn=mean(number), nd=sd(number))

ggplot(Db, aes(x=Cond, y=mn)) +
  geom_bar(stat="identity") +
  scale_y_continuous(trans = 'log2') +
  facet_grid(~Treatment)
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)) # use theme to change axis labels/angles
```

```{r boxplot}
ggplot(D, aes(x=Cond, y=number, colour=Cond)) +
  geom_boxplot() +                              # a boxplot summary
  geom_jitter() +                               # add actual data points
  scale_y_continuous(trans = 'log2') +          # on a logarithmic scale
  facet_grid(~Treatment)  +                     # "facet" over treatments
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90)) # use theme to change axis labels/angles
```

## Progress
- Rstudio
- Data classes: vector, matrix, data.frame, list = bags (e.g. lm, prcomp)
- Functions: Input, Ouput and Parameters (defaults)
- Visualizations: Basic, Heatmap, PCA
- Packages: Install and Invoke (library)
- Efficiency: History, Help, Notebooks

## Console, Environment and all that
- console = testing commands (trial & error)
- history = list of everything that was typed in console: savehistory("history.R") 
- environment = list of objects: save.image("env.Rdata"), load()

- script (.R)  = structured commands and reproducible R code: source(script.R)
- notebook/Rmarkdown (.Rmd) = annotated and documented scripts (knit --> html, pdf, docx)

## Central Dogma of Data Analysis

Read -> Check -> Filter -> Process -> Visualize -> Share

# 2020-04-17
## A brief glance: from plotting to modeling
```{r}
plot(Petal.Length ~ Petal.Width, data=iris)
cor(iris$Petal.Length, iris$Petal.Width)
fit=lm(Petal.Length ~ Petal.Width, data=iris)  # very simple, very powerful, very common
str(fit)      # this is a more complicated object:  a "list" = bag of things
summary(fit)  # the function summary() knows what we want to see from a fit
abline(fit)   # abline can deal with "fit". plot fit-line on the top of current "device" --> opened by plot
```
Many other functions are available to interact with such objects (plotting, predicting, ...)
Please refer to rmd/04_DataModels.Rmd for a full notebook on "linear modeling"

# 2020-04-14
## Functions

- Everything is a function: $y = f(x_1,x_2, \ldots, p_1, \ldots)$
- *structured* inputs: variables ($x_i$) and parameters ($p_i \to$ defaults?)
- *structured* outputs: $y$

Examples:
```{r}
sqrt(2)
sin(pi)
1+2
```
## Variables

- creation
- access: by index (`v[3]`), by name (`v["name"]`)
- recycling: `1:10 + c(1,2)`

Examples:
```{r variables}
# variable creation
x=exp(2)
v=sqrt(1:5)
names(v)=letters[1:5]

# variable access
v
v[3]    # by index
v["d"]  # by name
v[v<2]  # by logic

1:10 + c(1,2) # recycle
```


## Warning and errors

```{r warnings, eval=FALSE}
1:10 + c(1,2,3)
sqrt(-1:2)
```

```{r errors, eval=FALSE}
sqrt("a")
```
